messageBody:
tim_rice09 scripsit:

> A quick question, is there anyone in this group who speaks Scots? I've
> been researching it lately and am at a loss most of the time as to
> how it is actually spoken. Is it feasible to write Scots in Quickscript?

What a beautiful question!

I don't speak Scots, but I do know a little Scots phonology. First of
all, Insular Scots (Shetlandic and Orcadian) are out of the picture:
they can't reasonably be represented by the same orthography as the
rest of Scots, because their phonology is differently structured.
Fortunately, it's possible to create a diasystem that does a reasonable
job of handling the main dialect groups: Southern Scots, Central Scots
(South East, North East, West, South West, and Ulster), and Northern Scots
(South, Mid, North).

There are already enough consonant letters in QS to handle everything in
Scots, given the useful Loch letter on page 8 of the manual. The vowels,
as always, are the sticking point. To begin with, there is no distinction
between 30 At and 32 Ah in Scots, so I write 30 At here, both on account
of history and because it's easier to write in QS. In the same way,
39 Foot and 40 Ooze likewise never split in Scots, and we need only one:
for uniformity with English, I choose 40 Ooze.

The more serious issues are the Scots vowels with no QS equivalent.
31 I has to be split into two separate vowels for Scots: a long low
diphthong /aI/ as in _five_, and a short higher diphthong /@i/ as in
_nine_. The Scottish Vowel Length Rule separates these some of the time,
but not always. Aitken vowel 7, written _ui_ in the standard spelling
of Scots and variously pronounced /2/, /y/, /wi/, and /I/ in different
dialects, also needs its own vowel letter.

I'm assuming here that people who write Scots in QS want it to be read
by every Scots speaker; thus it's clearest if everyone writes 28 Why +
30 At for _wha_ (English 'who'), though Northern Scots speakers might
want to write 9 Fee + 30 At instead, since that's how they pronounce it.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
